comments.commentBody: Right, Gower Street has cheap student digs, with kitchens, and it's right in the heart of Bloomsbury, practically down the street from the British Museum (free) and lots of takeout places.  On Tottenham Court Road the Marks & Spencer has great take-out sandwiches, and there's always Testco.  Did you know you can visit Old Bailey and watch trials, just by climbing a load of steps?  And there are free concerts in the church of St. Martin's in the Fields at noontime (Trafalgar Square near the free museums) with an interesting cafe in the lower level.

Just a observation on who lives and dies in the multi-verse. The heroic captain lives on changing the future and in many a reality the travelers in the entire train survive. All but for Sean, the history teacher whose body Captain Colter occupies. Alas, history school teachers have no life.

I have not had the misfortune to sit through such self-indulgent rubbish in quite a while.  "An entirely new method of story telling".. "an organic tale of evolution and reincarnation".. One should laugh at the pretension.  Quite simply, the Emperor has no clothes.

How could anyone not think about getting back into the workplace when contemplating taking time off to raise kids? But in any case, working pat time is a good option, if your job and childcare situation allow--because that way, you keep your connections, skills, etc. Also agree with the poster who questioned "full-time parent." I work but am a FT parent, that's for sure :-)

To #3, while it's illegal to ask about a person's personal life in an interview, it's not illegal to point to a gap on a person's resume and say, "What were you doing then?" I think most employers would question a one- to six-year gap on a person's resume, and it's pretty hard as an applicant to explain its presence with anything other than the truth. Ensuring the truth contains some relevant experience, even if it's volunteer work, is the best way to handle the questions.

“The challenge … that many women — including me — didn’t think through was this: If I decide to remove myself from the workforce for a period of time, will I be able to get back in?"

Seriously - isn't that the major concern that any woman (man) would have before making such a decision. No way she didn't think about it. She might have decided to take the chance/risk anyway - but that is different from not having thought about it.
UConn's women would have won tonight's game.

The first words of encouragement I would give to the writer is that be glad you are a woman. Men who spend the same amount of time out of the work face magnified challenges. Women who stay at home with the children might be less common today but still meets a social/gender norm. Men who do so face a variety of judgment by employers for holding a role that goes against all traditional roles for men.

The sabbatical angle degrades the importance and positive impact upon children’s lives of stay at home parents. There may be data and research that says day care for infants and toddlers is “ok” but believe that parents-either gender-in the home during the early years has a positve and profound impact upon their development. I believe this positive influence also impacts the life of the stay at home parent as well.

Returning to any work, let alone one previous career field, is a challenge for all stay at home parents regardless of gender. It has been interesting experiencing the long list of double standards faced by husbands/fathers who become voluntarily unemployed/leave a career in order to care for the children, support their wife’s career, the family and keep the children out of day care. Although this family dynamic might be a small segment in society, some women might care to remind themselves that as difficult as their challenges are transitioning back to work, and I say this as gently as possible, you have no idea the difficulties men face.

I neither regret nor choose to re-label my time caring for my children. Caring for one’s children is not something that needs to be falsely titled and believe most employers would find it strange if not a distortion of reality. If anything, what this post reaffirms is that caring and nurturing ones children is downgraded to something that has to be labeled as something other than what it is.
I find it a sad reflection on society when women have to rebrand the time they took off work/career and cared for their children and family.

This is horrifying. Ideally, every school should have a nurse on site every day. However if that is beyond a school's budget, then there should be multiple employees (administrators, teachers, secretaries, etc.) who are First Aid/CPR/AED certified.

Mercedes Mears would probably have survived the episode had a lay responder with even minimal training been present and taken action. Red Cross CPR/AED certification can be completed in a single day, and would have given the adults present the knowledge and confidence necessary to step-in and save Mercedes's life.

My deepest sympathies go out to Mercedes's family, and I hope that this will be a wake-up call to schools everywhere that school-wide health and safety doesn't have to be all or nothing: even if there's no full-time (or even part-time) nurse, there is absolutely no excuse for not having someone on the school's staff complete a day of lay responder training and thus be prepared to save a child's life.
I subscribe to Motherlode on the RSS feed on my itouch.....updates each day!

I took an unexpected three-year leave from work when my kids were 3 months and 2 years old respectively. Given the circumstances, I was planning to return to work when my youngest was five, but it was simply not possible.

In 2008, when my younger daughter was 2 1/2 years, my husband lost his job in the financial crisis. I was able to call my former employer and explain the situation; I was offered my old job on the spot. Granted, I had good will there, but I also was regularly in touch with my colleagues - many of whom are good friends.

I made sure to stay on their radar - because I like them. If you really like the industry you're working in and want to return when your kids are older, stay in touch with the people who matter to you on a personal and professional level. Continue to have a mentor, have lunch with your former colleagues, exchange ideas and holiday cards.

I could not have predicted that a financial crisis would force me back to work two years earlier than I had planned - but having good will to start with, keeping in touch with my former colleagues, and keeping current in my profession sure worked for me when I needed it most.

Amy (#29): I am suggesting that we should, in the midst of an article about a drug to prevent a devastating disorder, expend a little bit of gratitude that simple treatment exists at all. That is what I'm suggesting.

And keep in mind that the FDA got involved in this for a good reason: to ensure the quality of the drug. If they hadn't, and there had been problems traceable to a poor manufacture of this drug, something tells me the *very same people* would be complaining about the lack of regulation by the FDA.

$640 a month for a prematurity drug of guaranteed purity is simply not that much.

Well said, #7. Call me when this woman has started a company that employs others and that sells something people want. Or when she starts doing worthwhile scientific research again. Or when she starts getting assigned important cases at a law firm. Writing a book about putting yourself together after SAH is the small leagues. How about a job where someone actually has to evaluate whether or not they want to hire you, or if they're going to keep you once they do?

Motherhood is not a profession. It is a state of being, maybe an occupation. But it will never be a profession until someone interviews you for it, compares you to the other possible candidates, tailors your future salary to your performance, and is willing to fire you if you don't perform. There is practically no barrier of entry to motherhood--and almost no one gets fired.

Sometimes I wonder if I am the only one in this situation....
yes, I was a stay at home mother for nearly 16 years...for 8 of those years, I was homeschooling, and there is no way I could have worked. After my kids entered school,and after my divorce, I went back to school to brush up on my skills...and tried to get into real estate appraisal ( bad timing) medical billing ( a scam, if there ever was one...for anyone trying to enter this field as a novice). I also volunteered for three years at my local hospital. When I mentioned to a doctor there that I was trying to find a job, he laughed, and said that he had never let his wife stay home, because he did not want her to end up like me...out of work. Nice. I quit volunteering soon after, and went back into antiquing, which I have done on and off for twenty years. I also buy and sell any kind of junk that will make me some money...started with selling off excess possessions. I get it that no employer wants me, so I am working for myself.

I saw the production in Los Angeles and almost left at intermission. I stayed for the remainder and was remarkably underwhelmed. Nominated for the Pulitzer??? What? Bottom line for me was that I didn't care about anyone on stage from beginning to end. I couldn't believe Isherwood's review! Had the show changed that much in the move to NY? Maybe I needed to see it again, because his review was not the show I saw. Turns out I'm not crazy and a lot of people had the same experience I did.
About the crowds: metal audiences here DO mosh. Please note.
How many really care what she does or doesn't  do?
Katie who ?  Leaving her last job was a big mistake on her part.
Though I haven't had a television in years I say go go go Katie. She's smart and intelligence is something American television lacks these days, big time. Put it on the net, so I can watch.

What a perfect year for college sports:  last year one NCAA Championship (in football) was erased (USC), the winner of this year's BSC Championship was disgraced -- Auburn in what was a transparent  NCAA coverup to avoid a second disqualification -- and now a proven rules violator -- University of Connecticut -- emerges as the NCAA men's basketball champion.   While hard-strapped "educational" institutions compete for coaches in the "money" sports (men's basketball and football) with multimillion dollar contracts, and coaches earn more millions for selling their team members' footwear rights, the formally unpaid "student athletes" get into NCAA trouble for selling their own athletic wear and awards (Ohio State).  Doesn't all this deserve a round of something other than applause?  Why should undergraduates and their parents shell out "tuition and fees" in tens of thousands of dollars to underwrite this wretched excess?  Enough.  End it.  Let the NFL, the NBA, the NHL and MLB run their own minor leagues.  Or  pay "student athletes" at least minimum wage and worker's compensation coverage for both practice time and game time because their efforts are earning the universities millions of dollars.  And disband the NCAA, or at least limit its bureaucrats to humanities faculty salary scale and watch it wither.   The charade is no longer even minimally amusing, and the costs are far too high.
Uconn played excellent defense, 10 blocks, and had enough offense. Jeremy Lamb was the difference in the second half and Alex O. owned the paint!

I think it's his first championship since 2004, not 1994...unless I'm a lot older than I thought.

Editor's note: Fixed. Thanks.
Boring end to an exciting tournament.

The women's games have been better! I love underdogs, and pulled for Butler--maybe next year.

Meanwhile, I cheered on the womenTexas Aggies; the game vs. Notre Dame ought to be good!! --- suggest you tune in and see some real competitive basketball!!

"An aging populace means that an ever-smaller share of Americans are working" That would be true if we had no growth in population but we have a steady growth in population. Also, these entitlements MUST be looked at and adjusted. If someone has a lot of money or income coming in, why do we pay them social security? Shouldn't we evaluate each retiree individually? SS has become so deeply engrained in this country that it will never go away but it needs to be looked at and corrected to insure it's survival.  Harry Reid is saying there's no problem with SS. Who is he kidding? We are now spending $8 for every $1 taken in, including entitlements. It's unsustainable and must be fixed.
